awd_titl_txt: Magnetostratigraphy of Cretaceous Sediments in the James Ross Island Basin, Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: 
The PI will collect samples to extend the magneto-stratigraphic record of late Cretaceous sediments of the James Ross Basin, Antarctica. RAPID support will allow him to take advantage of an invitation from the Instituto Antartico Argentino (IAA) to participate on an excursion to James Ross Island in the Antarctic Peninsula. The PI hopes to collect samples that will refine the position of several geomagnetic reversals between the end of the Cretaceous long normal Chron and the lower portion of Chron 31R. The Brandy Bay locality targeted by this expedition is the best place in the basin for calibrating the biostratigraphic position of the top of the Cretaceous Long Normal Chron, which is one of the most reliable correlation horizons in the entire Geological Time Scale.

Broader impacts: 
The top of the Cretaceous long normal Chron is not properly correlated to southern hemisphere biostratigraphy. Locating this event will be a major addition to understanding geological time. This expedition will provide opportunities for an undergraduate student. This project is based on a productive collaboration with an Argentine scientist.

por.por_cntn:
Near the end of the Antarctic Peninsula, the James Ross Basin contains a thick, detailed record of the profound paleoclimatic and paleontological change in Late Cretaceous time (~85-65 million years ago). Understanding the tempo and nature of warming, cooling, and extinction events, however, depends on having a robust time scale that will allow sediments deposited in one basin to be correlated temporally with those present in another. Very few traditional methods of correlation have proven usable in the James Ross Basin, presenting a problem in comparison to the rest of the world. Our magnetostratigraphy project—discovering magnetic reversals preserved in strata of the James Ross Basin—is establishing a reliable time scale with numerous global tie points. As a consequence, the fossil and climate records are finally beginning to be constrained in time, refining the precision of scientific questions that can be asked in Antarctica.

     The highly variable nature of the sea ice and weather has placed logistical constraints on working in the James Ross Basin. Some seasons are unpredictably unproductive due to conditions. Good seasons, such as in 2014, have been seized and have proven important for our success. At least for this proposed research we are taking advantage of two separate National Antarctic programs (IAA from Argentina, and OPP from the US), which gives us a good chance of completing the scientific goals within a reasonable time framework. On average, hundreds of samples spanning hundreds of meters of stratigraphic thickness have been collected and processed each year. The identification of critical magnetic reversals is creating the opportunity to correlate the Southern continent to elsewhere around the world for the first time in decades of paleoclimatic and paleontological study. Several convincing, reproducible magnetic reversal results are being prepared for publication.

     Both the field and laboratory components of the project are providing research opportunities for early career scientists. A Caltech postdoctoral fellow will have overseen and conducted two sampling campaigns, taking a leadership role that is important to assume at such a juncture in his professional development. In an international collaboration, an Argentinian graduate student from the University of Buenos Aires has taken part in multiple field campaigns as well as visited the Caltech laboratory multiply to conduct her magnetostratigraphy experiments. Two additional Argentinian graduate students have been involved in the fieldwork, including one who is carrying out her thesis work on the paleontology of the James Ross Basin.
